description.text: this 12 inch mirror reflects lots of light from an addressable LED strip.  I sized it to match the exact length of 1m 32 LED strip. I also cut spacers to make the mirrored surface and the front surface exactly parellel. this makes for a very nice straight infinite tunnel effect.

cut one face piece from 1/8 inch mirrored acrylic. leave the protective film in place or be very careful
cut one face piece from 1/8 inch clear acrylic. leave the protective film in place or be very careful.
cut eight spacer side pieces from 1/16 inch acrylic. these are the exact width of the LED strip i choose. 
I then found a good bending point on the strip and started sticking the spacer pieces to the strip.
cut nine of the slightly large edge pieces from 1/16 inch acrylic. glue these to the sides spacer pieces. use the extra to help with alignment.
bend the LED strip and two layers of acrylic around the clear front surface to test fit and sizing. remove protective film.  apply glue and plenty of pressure.
i taped the back mirror panel in place so it could be opened for cleaning and maintenance.
i added a wire all around the edge for hanging.
solder leads to an arduino. 
power up. 
enjoy.

Overall I used the 3D program Sketchup Pro 2015 to modify and transform a weapon specifically a pent-star shirikan into a flower pot. There's no picture of the final project because I decided not to print it out. The techniques i see to design and modify this creation was relatively simple, which is explained in the following inscription below. I had a lot of fun creating and modifying this creation. So if you want a unique flower pot that was originally a weapon then I suggest this 3D model creation is for you.

Since I used the 3D program sketchUp Pro I uploaded a premade pent-Satr shirikan from Thingiverse, which was created by rikkilambo. I chose it because I like the show Naruto and also the challenge of transforming a weapon into a object that would be the opposite of a weapon. In order to transform the shirikan into a flower pot I used shapes such as a square from the option box that has various shapes within the program. After choosing that option I drew a square on each end of the penti-star and then extruded each one downward. I also used the option box which allows the user to either use freehand draw or just draw straight lines onto the objects in the program. So by using the straight line option button I created triangle shapes, which I then extruded it outward with the extrude option button. Along with using the same option button I drew straight lines that connected each of the squares to form a base structure. In the program another option box i used was extrusion, which allows an object to be pulled forward and/or backwards. Lastly, I extruded the base triangles upward to give it depth along with leaving a small hole for the plant to growth out of and holes on the sides to allow for better access to the inside and space for the plant to grow out of as well.

This is a deprecated version. New version available here:
Flexible Landing Gear for Quadcopter "Crossfire" Version 2

Since the feet of my quadcopter "Crossfire" by MikeyB broke off during my very first test flight, I created these convenient, robust and flexible landing gears (you can drop the copter from about 30cm height with no problems, maybe even higher but I didn't test it higher). These landing gears aren't attached to the arms but to the bottom plate using the two screws which are already there. They also have hexagonal holders for the nuts to conveniently retighten the screws between flights. With 30% infill (recommended) this adds about 50 grams to your weight. Note: Depending on your screw length, nut size and print settings, you might want to fine-tune the nut holder. Make sure that the nut fits tight but doesn't break the layers apart when being screwed tightly.

When using different screws than M4 you have to change the size of the nut holder. The screw hole takes M3..M5. Print only one thing at once until you tested if it is good or should be fine-tuned. Print in 0.2-0.3mm layer height with 30-50% infill and 1 or 2 extra shells (= 2 or 3 diameters). No raft/support required if your printer can handle 45 degrees of overhang, which pretty much all do. When playing with these parameters, make sure the part where the nuts are placed is rigid enough, it will be the most fragile part of this thing. Using skeinforge, I used 0.2mm layer height, factor 1.8 width over height, 35% infill with 2 extra shells and 3 solid layers while printing at speed 60 maximum (at least in the layers with the nut holder).

Screw the top plate, arms, bottom plate and these landing gears with screws (M3..M5, model designed for M4, metal recommended) and put a nut (nylon recommended) in the nut holder. You can tighten the screw without holding the nut as it will be held automatically in place. The screw can be very tight. It might crack, but this is not critical. I did some extreme tests over-tightening the screw as much as I could; the layers broke apart on the outside but it still held together between the two screws without any problem.

author: DarthOctane

description.text:
I am a professional engineer, and I love to make robots.

I created this constructor kit to let children to learn coding of Arduino, Linux ROS (Robot Operating System, created by genius guys of Willow Garage) to prepare the engineers of tomorrow.

They can learn neural networks algorithms of ROS, which is running on Raspberry Pi model B with 1Gb of RAM, fully functional Linux computer for 35 USD, or newest Raspberry Pi 3.

The idea behind this kit is that A) it should be fully functional robot with the all same main capabilities as all those deployed in industry today, B) it should have so affordable price, that really any kid can make it, and C) if the kid does not have enough parts to build something, he or she can download and 3D-print them. Or design some unique parts which are not currently in the kit, and then 3D-print them.

I will keep this kit to be updated. All the hardware and software used is open-source (my design, Arduino, Linux, ROS) and all software is free.

It runs Linux Ubuntu 14.04.4 for ARM from here: https://wiki.ubuntu.com/ARM/RaspberryPi
It runs ROS from here: http://wiki.ros.org/indigo/Installation/UbuntuARM

If you want to buy this kit from me (all parts except electronic components), write to my email below.

Please if you will design additional parts, sent them to me to [email protected], and I will load them here as well, to let everybody to download the full kit. Also please send me any questions or suggestions you may have during the assembly of this robot, I will help you to solve them.

To see what is ROS, please google http://www.ros.org/ and https://www.google.com/webhp?sourceid=chrome-instant&ion=1&espv=2&ie=UTF-8#q=nasa.gov:+robonaut+2&tbm=vid
And please, dig deeper for best universities robotics courses on http://wiki.ros.org/ROS/Tutorials
Do you know that ROS-Industrial is supported by Kuka, Fanuc, ABB, UR and many others? Check out http://rosindustrial.org/news/

The main design pattern is: 7 mm holes, 15.5 mm between the centers of holes, width of the line is 28 mm, thickness of the element is 6 mm. Everything else - how you will do it :)

The nut (file "Knob") is specially designed so big, that small children cannot swallow it, can tighten it without the wrench, and tolerance is such, that they cannot take the nut out. You will need to hammer in it the steel nut 1/4" (6 mm) size.

All the bolts and nuts you can buy for ~5$ for 100 pieces in any hardware store, it uses 1/4"-20 (6 mm) thread and 6-32 thread. All servo holders are designed for standard size Hitec servos, and use 6-32 bolts and nuts, 1-1/4" length.

Important thing: use only original Arduino from official distributors (I used latest Arduino Mega 2560 from www.element14.com because it can handle a lot of servos and sensors). Chineese Arduino clones have not the latest processors and components, I have tried those, they cannot handle the current for the signals 5V to 9 servos, sensors and LEDs simultaneously, so they reload every several seconds.

Arduino screen is this one: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00ESYLLHA?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o06_s01

Beautiful Adafruit Raspberry Pi screen is this one: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B017PDWNKE?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o05_s00

GPS sensor with antenna from Adafruit:
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00I6LZW4O?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=od_aui_detailpages00

Tires are from here: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00W10IJEG?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o08_s01

Power supply for servos, Arduino and Raspberry Pi are these, I use 3 of them, two in parallel for 6V servos, and one for 5V Raspberry Pi supply: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B008ZNWOYY?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o06_s00

Battery is this, 4000 mAh x 3S: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00WLG0358?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o09_s00

Threaded rods are these ones: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00YWCRJU6?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o05_s00

Raspberry Pi kit with Wi-Fi and camera: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00UGBI91U?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00, or you can use the latest one: https://www.element14.com/community/community/raspberry-pi?ICID=hp-raspberrypi3-topbanner

Arduino Mega servo shield: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B007PABRNM?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o07_s00

Three servos Hitec 32645S HS-645MG for hand and gripper: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B003T6RSVQ?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o05_s00

I used servos Hitec HS-311 for wheels, and easily modified them for continuous rotation. You can use them as well, they are 8 USD per servo: https://www.servocity.com/html/hs-311_standard.html, or you can use more strong ones, with dual ball bearings and metal gears. I used HS-311 because thought that 8 USD is the right price for a kid to begin learning robotics. But if your budget is not so tight, you can use Hitec 1425CR continuous rotation servo with dual ball bearings, 20 USD each, it works better.

Two distance sensors, front and back: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00IMOSEJA?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00

LEDs: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B004UMA60S?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o03_s00 (red for back) and http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0059H5ZHM?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o03_s00 for front lamps, and 7x9 cm PCBs to mount them in a hexagonal rows: http://www.amazon.com/dp/B012YZ2Q0U/ref=twister_B012YZ2PYC?_encoding=UTF8&psc=1

On-off toggle switches, 2 pieces, one for Arduino shutdown, one for Raspberry Pi shutdown: http://www.amazon.com/Toggle-ON-OFF-Switch-spade-terminals/dp/B014BVWHW2?ie=UTF8&psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o07_s00

If you want, you can add radio control:
http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__190__190__Radios_Receivers.html?idCategory=190&pc=

Enjoy, I hope you will like it! :)
Nick
[email protected]
(C) Designed in California

List of references:

Very good Arduino lessons from Paul McWhorter: http://www.toptechboy.com/arduino-lessons/
Very good Raspberry Pi Linux lessons from Paul McWhorter: http://www.toptechboy.com/raspberry-pi-with-linux-lessons/
ROS Tutorial 1 "TurtleBot in Gazebo Simulator" by Justin Huang: https://youtu.be/9U6GDonGFHw
ROS Tutorial 2 "Subscribers & Publishers" by Justin Huang:
https://youtu.be/bJB9tv4ThV4
Original "SLAM for dummies" by Søren Riisgaard and Morten Rufus Blas: http://ocw.mit.edu/courses/aeronautics-and-astronautics/16-412j-cognitive-robotics-spring-2005/projects/1aslam_blas_repo.pdf
Print Settings

Printer Brand: Robo 3D
Printer: R1 ABS + PLA Model
Rafts: No
Supports: Yes
Resolution: 0.2 mm
Infill: Just usual support, without "Support everywhere"

Notes:
Top and bottom layers: 6 counts, 1.2 mm Extrusion multiplier: 1.03 I use only red and yellow Hatchbox PLA, D = 1.75 mm to print my parts. You can use any other colors: blue with yellow, orange with green, blue with white etc. I recommend to use only PLA, because it is so much easier to print than ABS! It does not shrink, does not peel off from the bed, sticks easy, flows easy and accurately, gives shiny glossy finish when done. I never use ABS in my prints. I print all parts except "Knob" with 2 perimeters layers, 30% infill. "Knob" I print with 2 perimeter layers, 40% infill. Infill type - triangles, they hold the shape well.

comments.text: Good design but I had a failure at the transition area. I didn't observe the failure so I don't know if some anomaly caused it, and I don't remember what level of infill I used, but I thought I would let you know. A larger fillet radius at the transition might make this part stronger. Thanks for your design, though!
comments.author: smratalleck

comments.text: interesting. i have been sporting mine now for a year and an half. its quite strong.  its not really my design though. its just the stock makergear holder stl that i resized. it was a very quick remix. it should be really strong if printed in abs. with that said though im sure a fillet would add strength. thanks for the heads up.

Wheel Volvo Jakob OV 4

A piece for a Triforce necklace from the Legend of Zelda franchise!

NOTICE: String not included. You'll have to find one yourself. Sorry.
NOTICE 2: Edges of the Triforce may be fragile due to it's thinness. Be careful.

If there is some sort of issue with it (for instance, it being a little too small or the hole being too small), please let me know. If it is something that you want alone, I will make a copy of it to fit your preference. Note that I will not be able to do this for everyone, I may have to cancel that idea if it starts becoming overused. At that point, I will only fix major issues. Also, keep in mind that it is not guaranteed to work correctly. I have not printed it myself yet, so I do not know. If you want to print it, that's fine. Just note that I don't want anyone coming to me about it. If it is messed up, let me know. I'll try and fix it (pretty much what I said above). CHECK MY BIO FOR MORE INFO ON THIS ISSUE. PRETTY MUCH THE SAME INFO THOUGH.

There isn't much to it.

Step 1: Download thing.
Step 2: Print thing.
Step 3: Make sure that said thing printed properly.
Step 4: Find a string that is small enough to fit through the hole.
Step 5: Make sure that said string fits you as well.
Step 6: Tie string or enforce it together some other way.
Step 7: Wear your new Triforce necklace. Or don't. That's fine too.

title: LM8LUU Bearing Block for Wanhao Duplicator I3

description.text:
Update 5/10/16
I noticed the bearing became loose in the mount after around 40 hours of printing. I drilled some holes between the lock-nut blocks and ran zip-ties around the bearing. When I have time I'll update the design to include holes for the zip-ties.

I took chinkel's great bearing block design and made a cutout in it. This allows it to be used on my Monoprice Maker Select's X-axis without rubbing on the belt. The bearings simply snap into the holders and do not need spacers or snap rings.

You will need:
4 x m4 lock nuts
2 x m4x20mm bolts
2 x m4x10mm bolts

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3

Infill:

30

Notes:

Printed with 2 shells and they are plenty strong.

comments.text: Did you have to use any o-rings at all? With this can you skip buying those o-ring pliers? Also, for your second x-axis lock, did you just use chinkel's original?
comments.author: jwx23

comments.text: No orings or c-clips are needed. The bearings just snap in. The bottom block is the original design.
comments.author: jwx23

comments.text: Excellent! So you're saving people time, money, and hassle. Sounds like the makes should be going up shortly!
comments.author: pb300

comments.text: Printed these but M4 would not press fit in at all, bearing clip in perfectly, think I got the wrong size nylocks!
comments.author: Clwebb

comments.text: The lock nuts were a tight press fit on mine. I got them started then flipped the block over on my bench and forced them in. Now that I've calibrate the extrusion rate for each filament I have they would probably fit looser.
comments.author: Clwebb

comments.text: Wouldn't super-gluing the bearing into the holder solve the problem of becoming loose?
comments.author: docpayce

comments.text: I tried that initially but I hadn't cleaned the bearings first so it didn't stick.
comments.author: docpayce

comments.text: I tried that now and that bearing is in use for like a month now without any problems. I used a generous amount of superglue on all touching surfaces and cleaned the bearing with alcohol before attaching it. Works like a charm. If I ever run into problems, I will report back.
comments.author: pb300

comments.text: Just fyi: Still works flawlessly. :) Method recommended.

print_settings.Notes:: Print in any material on a heated bed. This needs to stick.

description.text:
Assassin's Kit-Close Range

Have you ever been playing a video game like Assassin's Creed or something and wished you were the assassin? Well, now you can be like one of those killers with the Close Range Assassin's Kit!

This beautiful collection of weapons has all you need to begin as a close range Assassin!*
The kit contains:
1 Compact pistol
1 Throwing knife
1 Combat knife
1 Tomahawk
1 Dual-explosion grenade

Can be manufactured in separate parts, or as one large sheet.

*Disclaimer: Weapons are non-lethal

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1-0.15

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Print in any material on a heated bed. This needs to stick.

Usage

Compact Pistol: If you're ever a bit far, say, a hundred feet or so, just take this baby out and pop the people down! Holds 17 rounds.
Throwing Knife: At around ten to fifty feet, choose a trajectory and throw this underhand. Go for a fatality.
Combat Knife: Use at close range to stab/hack, use in conjunction with pistol to take out squads of corrupt guards.
Tomahawk: Use like the throwing knife, although hacking and slashing is also advisable.
Dual-Explosion Grenade: Drop it down a roof or vent. The first explosion will disable everyone within 10 feet and every device in the building-a shrapnel bomb and an EMP blast. The second one will be much larger and finish the job.

comments.text: I agree with him none of your designs are worthy of the Assassin's if they were real. do you even know what a tomahawk is. and the only thing worth printing on here is probably the throwing knife.

comments.text: Dude, I'm sorry but...this is just bad. These models need a LOT of work to be passable.

author: etdouglas

title: Warp Test for Print Bed Adhesion

description.text:
This model (actually set of three models) is a torture test to see if you can print it without any warping or lifting of the ends. I'll bet you can't.

I have not found a single FDM 3D printer that can print this model in ABS without warping and still allow a clean release of the finished print, unless my new printing surface is installed.

The thing that makes this model such a bear to print is the fact that it has only a 1/8" wide contact patch at the bottom of the V-shaped body. This tiny contact patch does not allow very much adhesion, so the forces of the contracting cooling plastic from each successive layer wants to pull the ends up off the print bed, causing warping.

There are three versions of this model as follows: 1.) Completely solid, 2.) A hollow shell, and 3.) A hollow shell with a vertical partition in the center to impart even more warping force on the ends.

This is the hardest thing that I have ever tried to print without having the ends lift up and warp off the print bed.

Many of you know that I have been working on a novel printing bed with a special surface specifically designed for printing in ABS. I have been trying to solve the ABS adhesion problem for many years, and I was the first one to publish the method now known as ABS juice or ABS slurry. The new print surface is the perfect combination with ABS slurry.

I built this model as a torture test for that new print surface.

I am recording GoPro videos of the build on my new surface material today (4/19/2016), and will update this post as soon as the video is done.

My new build surface is designed to still use ABS slurry, but the great thing is that this surface has tremendous adhesion when it is hot, but no adhesion when it is cool. It is also completely resistant to acetone and solvents, and can be heated to 1150 degrees F without damage (your printer will be damaged at that temperature, but not the print surface). This new print surface is also not made from any kind of glass (all types of glass including borosilicate and tempered glass are prone to thermal shock and can chip or crack or even shatter if the temperature of the glass changes too rapidly). Instead of glass, this new surface is made from a very thin sheet of a very special form of ceramic metallic oxide, which is extremely rigid. It is then coated with a special compound and fused to the rigid material in order to produce a bed that has nearly identical thermal expansion characteristics to ABS when it is hot, but radically different thermal expansion characteristics than ABS plastics when it is cold. This causes the finished part to be easily lifted off the build surface when it has cooled.

As you probably know all too well, the problem with ABS slurry is that it makes your printed parts stick too well to the build surface. The most common solution is to stick Kapton tape on the print bed, and then apply ABS slurry to the Kapton tape. ABS slurry helps the part stick to the Kapton tape on the print bed, but the warping forces will often cause the adhesive of the Kapton tape to actually separate from the bed. We are talking about some major contraction forces here! If the 3D printed sticks OK to a particular surface like Kapton or glass with ABS slurry without warping, usually when you try to remove the model, it won't budge. The only solution in this case is to use a scraper, knife blade, or screwdriver, but you risk scratching the print bed or damaging your finished part.

I think you will be impressed by my new build surface for printing in ABS. Here are the main features (this is not a commercial!):

o Thin and extremely rigid and stiff
o Very strong, unlike fragile glass
o No issues with thermal shock causing cracks, warping, shattering, or chipping
o Hot-swappable so you can start a new print as soon as the first one is finished
o Have multiple beds prepped and ready to go
o Literally pick up the finished printed part from the bed when it is done
o No modifications to your printer
o No fastening hardware or clips
o Not affected by heat, solvents, and resistant to abrasion

We will be testing the surface with a number of selected beta testers, as well as at all our 11 TechShop locations worldwide and all our TechShop Inside maker trailers.

If you are interested in being a beta tester (at a 50% discounted price) and you normally print in ABS with your heated-bed ABS printer, please PM me with your information and the type of printer you have, along with the dimensions of the print bed, and I'll put you on the consideration list. I'm hoping to get beta testers all set up starting in May 2016.

Anyway, try printing these models on your printer in ABS (or PLA if that's all you have) and post a photo here showing how much you can avoid warping, and print a finished part with a perfectly flat bottom.

Good luck!

--
Jim Newton
Founder, TechShop

Printer:

FlashForge Dreamer

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

To Print:

Orient this model so the small flat surface (1/8" wide by 9" long) is in contact with your print bed, then print it.

I'm printing on a FlashForge Dreamer in ABS using Simplify3D with the following settings:

o No support
o No rafts
o 100% fill
o 0.2mm layer height
o ABS slurry on the special print bed surface
o 105c print bed temperature
o 230c extruder temperature
o Black HatchBox brand ABS filament

comments.text: Was this new print bed surface ever released/finished? I was looking for it online but the website was closed.

Here is a dissection of a 6x6x6 cube into eight pieces. It is meant to show visually that 3^3 + 4^3 + 5^3 = 6^3. The eight pieces make the 6x6x6 cube, and the pieces contain a 3x3x3 cube and can be used to make 4x4x4 and 5x5x5 cubes. It came from a Figure in a book by Harry Lindgren with a reference to R. F. Wheeler dated 1951. OpenSCAD code is included.

Doesn't Matter

0.3 mm

Microphone stand for desktop. Made in solidworks. 31mm Inner Diameter, will spread to 32 or 33. I printed with the Buzzed filament made with beer!

Trying my hand at a few architectural styles. These will be used to flesh out my stonepunk alien village (WIP) though I could imagine them being useful for any number of settings. This would be an easy piece to scale up. For 18mm, scale up by 120%, and for 28mm, scale up by 180%.

We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested in helping to fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Wayfarer Tactics. and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! (Psst... we take requests and commissions...)

Enjoy!

description.text:
Ever tried to record a video, but you need to move the camera and have both hands free? Here is the solution.

Please tell me if you have other phone you want this idea modeled with. I need the Thickness & width.

Print IBITE Galaxy 6s Hat clip
Slide Galaxy 6s Phone into clip
Slide Gator's Mouth onto the brim of your had
Press record and enjoy

I have found it easier to look above the camera (Between the camera and the hat brim) than try to focus on the screen. If the screen was set back 100mm from your eyes you could use this to watch videos on a car ride or airplane.

Added horizontal-positioned model. This one might create a lot of supports and might be a little bit harder to detach, but there's more guarantee that it will come out well. Don't use Raft!

description.text: Zell am See in Salzburg Austria constructed using 1 arcsecond resolution SRTM data from the Space Shuttle (about 0.5 million facets). This software was created using a new and, as yet, unreleased version of SRTM2STL. The source code for creating files at 3 arcsecond resolution is available up on github under the GNU license. Go to github and search for SRTM2STL.

lidInsetOffset = 0.0
rimInset = 0.6
sidewallWidth = 1.1
hingeFillet = 3

Small box that can be wired up to allow an ESP-12 module (ESP8266 based) to fit into a breadboard. Each hole needs a wire pushed through it, then these should be pushed through the holes on the ESP module, and soldered in place.

The holes are 1.5mm diameter.

UPDATE: version 4 supports the contacts on the short side of the 12E and 12F modules. These are on a rather shallow angle, and the tunnels are quite close together, so you should probably test to make sure the wires aren't touching if using this version.

UPDATE2: version 3short is a 2mm high version, and 3narrow is narrower at the breadboard end so it only takes up the inner row of the breadboard.

title: RunCam Swift FPV adjustable camera mount (with bumpers) for Emax Nighthawk 250

description.text:
RunCam Swift FPV camera mount with bumpers. Mount allows full camera uptilt from ~2 degrees to 45 degrees. The lens remains behind the bumper protection for crashes when angeled below 43 degrees. The bumpers also protect the lens from any prop debris and dust.

Prints upside-down

The Swift is similar to the Sony HS1177 camera but also comes with a different back plate that allows for locking in the uptilt angle.

title: Tea Light to 3/8th inch dowel rod adapter

description.text:
Odd item. A tealight holder that sits on the end of a dowel rod. A solution a to a problem a teacher had while helping with the school play.

"how could they attach an LED tealight to the end of a dowel rod?"

I just bought a 3d printer. Lulzbot mini. This was my first attempt at anything in openSCAD. Seriously, I just picked up the program today and read a few tutorials. The item isn't complicated and this is only the first iteration.

The print turned out really nice (again, I don't have many standards yet since this is the 12th actual print I've ever done period. I was super pleased with myself. )

I plan on just making everything thicker in general, but the items I need to measure aren't available so I figure at least some proof of concept would be nice to show them.

title: TCG Deck Box - UltraPro Original Satin Tower Mock

description.text:
Ever sense I started dueling these deck boxes were the blingy-est of bling that I had known, eventually acquiring one myself that I've had for 10+ years. In an attempt to buy more I have discovered that UltraPro has stopped production of these wonderful things.

This fact, my capabilities, and my urge to have more; brought me to creating this 'clone' like design.

If you are curious there is another style where the deck box opens from the side and is oriented horizontally rather then vertically. I'll be adding that one to this thing in a week or two.

I have no wish to steal any intellectual property this is merely my attempt at remaking a now discontinued, and 'obsolete' product.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.1

Infill:

15-30%

Notes:

Edit: Dec. 2016 Got these guys printed finally, they worked just fine with the thickness of the inner tabs. However please note it is better to print these at 2 shells. I tried at 3 and they did not have enough initial give to allow ease of slide on and off.

If you are printing this be careful, the inlet latch of DeckBox.Up.Case uses a thickness of 1.5mm, so if your printer isn't calibrated or up to the task of printing such a fine wall it will most likely end horribly. Until I get a chance to print this (somehow) I am not sure how viable this design is. If its the case were I can not get it printable I will alter the design overall to make a more accommodating wall.

As it is now you do not need to print off any of the DeckBox.Symbol files, but if you do please note these will need to be glued on.

These files should be printable without support, let me know how that goes!

description.text:

Please download the PDF file for the guide under Thing Files.

The latest version of this tutorial is available online at https://www.munfred.com/proteins.html

title: Midi Fighter Classic - Arcade Button MIDI Controller

description.text:
This is the top and bottom plates for a DJ TechTools Midi Fighter Classic (Arcade Button DJ/MIDI/Music Controller).

It's great as a custom or replacement top plate for a Midi Fighter classic, since they are no longer for sale. It also works great as a top and bottom plate for any DIY MIDI or arcade button controller using 24mm Sanwa arcade buttons.

Lastly, they work great as stencils if you'd like to use other materials such as wood or metal.

**Update: I've created and added the side enclosure to make the full controller. You can user 24mm arcade buttons or 3D print these: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1400499 (Just scale them up 190%) and mount a small/cheap tactile button (http://amzn.to/2coYxgQ) inside them and you have a fully functioning/fully printed midi controller.

Recommended to complete the project:

-Teensy 2.0 circuit board: http://amzn.to/2d05u8O
-Sugru Moldable Glue for mounting buttons: http://amzn.to/2cp0k5E
-Full tutorial on how to wire/code: http://djtechtools.com/2015/08/25/how-to-make-your-own-diy-midi-controller/

Printer:

XYZ DaVinci 1.0 Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

10%

Notes:

Brim not needed, but a small 5mm Brim on all 3 parts will prevent warping since it will take a few hours to print each.

Print top and bottom plates at 3mm height.

comments.text: It seems scaling the model by 125% when you import it will achieve a close result (close enough for me) but of course the LED and screw holes and channels are going to be different as well.
comments.author: Chyno32488

comments.text: Ah, sorry.  Unfortunately, I built this based on a schematic of the actual DJ TechTools MidiFighter, which uses 24mm buttons.  However you could always scale the print up a few percentages to maybe 115% or 120%, may take some trial and error prints, but once you do that you can scale the other pieces the same percentage to fit.  That may give you close to what you need, or you could drop the STL file into 123Design or say Tinkercad to adjust the file.

title: Ducted extruder carriage for Rapman
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Replacement for the acrylic single-head Rapman extruder carriage.
This design incorporates a fan duct that more effectively cools the area being printed, reducing curling and melting.
Also holds the extruder fastening bolts securely, without them loosening and turning like the standard ones frequently did on my Rapman. Added July 2014: a couple of modifications!
bkt60a.stl is a bracket that bolts onto the top of the rear end of the extruder carriage that allows a 60mm fan to be mounted and pointed at the top of the hot end. On my printer, this has totally prevented the heatsoak problem causing PLA to jam the hot end.
duct shield.stl is a simple shield that attaches to the main duct at the bottom, shielding the tip of the hot end from the airflow, thus improving temperature stability.

• Purchase a PC cooler fan designed to fit into an expansion card bracket - I used an Antec branded one but there are plenty of physically identical generic ones.
  • Take the PC case bracket off the fan, and insert the fan into the upper piece and drill through to allow a bolt to secure the fan.
  • Fix up the wiring by either replacing the Rapman fan power socket with a molex plug (what I did) or vice versa.
  • Insert the extruder fastening bolts into the upper piece from underneath. A good friction fit is best; tightening a washer and nut on the opposide side will pull the bolt snug. If the bolt is loose, some tape will suffice - the act of installing the extruder will pull the bolts snug.
  • After removing print support from the middle and lower pieces, glue them together using your favourite adhesive. I use brown shoe glue.
  • Install using original extruder carriage hardware (you won't need all the bolts though)
    NB: ductl3.bfb.zip is sample output generated using KISSlicer, 0.2mm layers using PLA

comments.text:
Hi
Great design. What is the possibility to add duct for a 40mm fan on the other side to cool the cold end of the print head. I find my extruder over heating when doing long abs prints as well as larger rafts. the overheating occurs at the cooling stage after the raft has been laid down ,
Thanks
Deon
comments.author: noedger

comments.text: i've played around with 40mm fan placement but clearance is an issue at least for 15mm fans - putting it at the back left / right (~45 degrees around from the back and any/all of the following get in the way:
comments.author: noedger

comments.text: Is there anyway i can get the original copy id like to turn this into a dual extruder. or if you could take and double these side by side (already measured this and same measurements) i also have some extra lm8uu'sfor the linear bearings
comments.author: rapmanreject

comments.text: i model directly in the polygon format you see in the STL, so feel free to modify and improve them :)
comments.author: rapmanreject

comments.text: Great looking design. I am in the middle of printing the upper part, and it is warping pretty badly. Any suggestions (using ultimachine black ABS)?
comments.author: asifjahmed

comments.text: A little bit of warping is ok, it should still fit together and work. The only problem it may cause is the extruder sits 1-2mm higher than it should, but as long as it still hits the X limit switch it should be fine.
comments.author: asifjahmed

comments.text: Having my ABS copy finished... is PLA strong enough for it?  I remember now why I was doing everything in PLA... not that it seems like it would be unusable, but I don't care for all the gaps, especially in the duct area between the U and M pieces.
comments.author: chylld

comments.text: I've never used regular BFB PLA, I'd imagine it should be ok. I use orbi-tech PLA and both the 45 and 90 versions are strong enough.
comments.author: Kenku

comments.text: Hm; for some reason in trying to print the lower section (possibly others; I'd started with the lower section first though) it's leaving a hollow shell through most of the duct.  That is to say, there's a one-layer-thick line of ABS on the outside profile, a similar line on the inner profile, and an air gap between them.  Part was generated in Axon2 at 100% fill; any advice for what to look for on why it's doing that?
comments.author: Kenku

comments.text: The angled walls are a bit less than 2mm thick, which causes Axon/SF to leave a gap since there isn't enough room for 2 inner paths.
comments.author: Kenku

comments.text: Aha, a different slicing program; that explains everything!  That's interesting in how differently it generates the baseplate (or whatever the favored terminology is) and moves.  Got it going in ABS as I type this.
comments.author: chylld

comments.text: my original design actually accommodated an 80mm fan, and was designed to attach to the underside of the standard acrylic extruder carriage. however after 3 prototypes i couldn't get even airflow since radial fans don't provide consistently strong pressure. i actually felt more air coming out the intake side of the fan!
comments.author: Kenku

comments.text: Decided on a Sunon blower; it should be moving about twice the air of the Antec cooler.  Not a direct bolton, but I figure making a little bracket and epoxying it to the upper half should be pretty trivial.  If that's not enough air (and/or noise) I'll try one of the famed Delta finger-chopper fans with an adapter... or maybe I'll do so anyway in the spirit of experimentation.  ;)  Though to do that, I'll probably have to rig a relay so that it doesn't kill the fan controller... I can't imagine the BFB controller was intended to be able to supply a couple amps to the fan.   O:-)
comments.author: chylld

comments.text: Good luck with the sunon blower, let us know how it goes :)
comments.author: Kenku

comments.text: Well, minor setback; the middle section seems to have printed a bit "tight" around the linear bearings, and I failed to notice this until I broke off the mount tab by the single bearing.  Whoops.  Time to print another one.
comments.author: chylld

comments.text: hmm i remember scaling my model down (or was it up?) to fit my machine, even though I measured with calipers beforehand. so the model may actually be printing a bit larger or smaller than it should be.
comments.author: Kenku

comments.text: I didn't measure the spacing between the bearings; in truth I think it may be both, but it seemed primarily to be tightness around the individual bearings.  I'll have to play with the kisslicer settings later... for this piece I think I may just cheat and use my milling machine to get the tolerances right, and see what the stringing/boogering looks like with better cooling.
comments.author: chylld

comments.text: Let me know how you go - I might need to revise it to accommodate some slack wrt bearing housing proportions. Now that I think about it, there's really not that much need to have a 100% snug fit around the bearings....
comments.author: Kenku

comments.text: Also I should mention I'm using a beta version of the upcoming KISSlicer Pro, which I assume performs quite a bit better than the old command-line version...
comments.author: chylld

comments.text: Mm; I'm waiting to have the creator of that take my money.  Once I get this thing to where I have proper cooling, I have a bunch of rapman corners to print, and no real good way to bundle .stl files...
comments.author: chylld

comments.text: I just talked to him, shoot him an email (lonesock at gmail dot com) and he'll set up you up the latest Pro version :)
comments.author: Kenku

comments.text: Went and made an adapter duct for the Sunon blower I bought for this. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:15727http://www.thingiverse.com/thi... if you're curious; not sure whether I should be listing it as a derivative or what. ;)
comments.author: chylld

comments.text: Nice one! I think your design skills are better than mine :)
comments.author: Kenku

comments.text: I don't know about that; I mean I'm pretty sure that, if I were to have tried to do the rest of the extruder carriage instead of using yours, it would have ended up looking something like a large box with ducts in it somewhere instead of something actuall elegant.
comments.author: chylld

comments.text: Got it adjusted to mostly fit... I think it may need to be adjusted a touch, as I had to use a dremel sander to open up the linear bearing bores and move them inwards.  But it was also a not particularly clean print in the first place, which is obviously on me.  ;)
comments.author: Kenku

comments.text: Apparently there is such a thing as too much fan; what seems to happen is that the fan is capable of cooling the extruder head faster than it can heat up, so the fan kicks on and off periodically.  Time to get a rheostat.
comments.author: Kenku

comments.text: wow that fan is huge! no wonder you have "too much" cooling.
comments.author: Kenku

comments.text: I was thinking the same thing, actually.  Well, or entirely-too-drastic modifications to the hot end to kick out more heat capacity, but I should probably just file that as a last resort.  I suspect I can knock together a shield out of stuff I have laying around without much trouble.
comments.author: chylld

comments.text: Well done!  Knowing you think things through I have some questions on your design:
comments.author: Makezilla

comments.text: 1) Yes I was going to do that, but decided that it's stable enough at this distance. The extruder (relative to the extruder's own base) is the weakest part stability-wise and that's in the Y direction
comments.author: Makezilla

comments.text: I knew you'd have thought about moving the bearings out.  I have thought about using non-self aligning bearings for the dual rod and one of the Y axis rods as well.  Use them to stiffen things up and the self-aligning to to allow for the error....I am installing CAD software I am familiar with and will transfer the napkin designs I have for the X and Y to CAD at that point.  There are so many good ideas and good thinkers on this site it is a pleasure to swap ideas....more to follow.
comments.author: chylld

comments.text: Interesting idea. I think the 12mm X/Y rods are stiff enough to not need them, but maybe you are thinking more laterally than I am :)
comments.author: Makezilla

comments.text: To prioritize improvements stability of the X-Y movement is not a big offender by the looks of mine.  The Z, which you have attacked with a gusto is a better spot to devote time.  Thanks and of course...more to follow.
comments.author: chylld

comments.text: Getting the dimensions off the machine is quite the process.  Did you gather yours manually or did you have a "source"? (Any chance of me getting the 2D files in a DXF format?  I have placed your STL into my evolving model and see the bottom of the ducts are ~5.6mm above the bottom of the nozzle.  Again...I trust there is a logical reason...and I have read what you told KENKU about too much vs. too little.  Would be nice if BFB would put a PWM control to the can to adjust air flow via AXON.  By the way, do you use AXON?
comments.author: Makezilla

comments.text: I gathered them by trial and error :) I used calipers to get a rough starting point, but that only gets you in the ballpark and further refinement is always required. ~5mm sounds right.
comments.author: Makezilla

comments.text:
Okay...I'm finding massive dimensional discrepancies on the parallel characteristics of the X and Y axis. Fixed the X (,762mm) with a set of gage blocks and a nylon tie. The 1,52mm of the Y is a little more challenging. Frankly, I doubt anyone using stock components doesn't have errors that are at least similar...And to think this all started with wondering if I could add lights to your ducted sled....yikes! BTW...I'm sure the sleds/trolleys whatever to call them for both the X
&
amp; Y contribute to the instability of the Z...which is a bigger nut to crack.
comments.author: chylld

comments.text: Compliments great job!
comments.author: Clax

comments.text: thanks clax :)
comments.author: Clax

After struggling with the original glass holders of K8400 and later with re-sized hotbed clips from diegudio http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:240181 I came up with this simple solution that works very well.
In my initial design I made an assumption that the glass has the same dimensions as underlying frame. In fact, my glass is 0.25mm wider. So, I had to alter the set of left holders. Sharing both left sets. The wider set contains 025 in the thing names.
Measure your glass and frame before printing. You may need to do your own adjustments.
fl, rl, fr and rr in thing file names mean front-left, rear-left, front-right and rear-right. The side pieces are identical.

Use M3x8mm screws to mount all 6 pieces to the frame.

print_settings.Notes:: Print with 3 shells (1.2mm thickness) and 1.2mm top/bottom to match.  The top/bottom thickness gives it strength to prevent it bending inward to contact the fan hub.

description.text:
I was looking at extruder fan grilles for my Maker Select, and considered a few, but they all seemed to have one or another near-fatal flaw. This is my attempt to combine ideas from all the grilles I looked at and solve their flaws.

The hexagon pattern is specifically made with ribs .8mm wide to ensure two nozzle passes using the stock .4mm nozzle, and to restrict a minimum of airflow. Orignially the hex pattern went all the way across, but then I remembered why we use these: to protect the fan while giving us a place to push the carriage. This is where the central disk came in.

The next problem to solve was mounting it. Other designs have their own well for the screw head, which can affect how much thread engages with the motor body. M3x55 or M3x60 screws can he hard to find, so I avoided that possibility altogether by just making the holes for the screws to pass through.

Some other designs use slotted pins. I printed two iterations with slotted pins, and the pins broke off of both of them. Another option I considered and discarded was to integrate small clips into the design. I considered the bottom side a hot zone unsuitable for PLA, and the heat sink severely limits clip size. So that was out.

The only mounting soliution left was press fit. That is, solid pins that are just oversize for an M3 hole to hold the grille in place by friction. The pin diameters match the screw size at the ends, but bulge out to .25mm more than the screw size in the middle. The narrow end helps with insertion, and because some fans have head wells on one or both sizes of the fan chassis, the only reliable hold area was the middle, hence the bulge.

The slots around the back edge are to aid in removing the grille if the fit is tight. Insert a flat screwdriver and twist so that the side of the slot near the pin gets pulled away.

Variation in fan design is why there are two versions. Some fans have M3 holes, other have M4. Each file is named for the screw size that matches the pins. If you have a stock fan, use the M3 version.

The M3 grille I printed fits with barely any force required, yet doesn't rattle and hasn't fallen off.

EDIT: The 'b' files add .05mm diameter to the thick part of the pins (to nominal + .3mm), which should make for a tighter fit.

Printer:

Maker Select

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

Print with 3 shells (1.2mm thickness) and 1.2mm top/bottom to match. The top/bottom thickness gives it strength to prevent it bending inward to contact the fan hub.

Pin cleanup

After printing, it's likely that the pins will be messy. Carefully scrape any excess material off the pins. Make sure they are smooth and glob-free before mounting.

comments.author: briancsmith

title: Anti-wobble bed holders for Rapman
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
These bed holders/corners aim to solve the dreaded XY wobble arising from crooked threaded rods. They also prevent the upper bed from shaking with respect to the lower bed on the 3 sprung M8 bolts. Finally they allow fine bed height adjustment at 4 corners rather than just 3 points.
This is version 15 of my design and the best so far, but it does not remove wobble 100%. I am very receptive to ideas to improve it. To give you an idea of my early designs, here is a youtube video of version ~8:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LSeArlGSxtA
Installing these will be a hassle the first time as partial disassembly is required to remove the original bed holders. However my replacements are designed to be easily upgradable so please bare with the pain :)
I realise there are a lot of steps below, but it is quite simple and a lot of it will be obvious just by looking at the photos. The only tricky parts you need to obtain are 12x linear bearings (the same type used on the X and Y belt idlers) and 8x 35mm-long M3 bolts. These quantities are for a full installation of 4 bed holders, which I recommend as it would be tricky to mix and match these with the original bed holders.
PS I have quite a few bearings and 35mm M3 bolts left over, if anyone in Australia wants some, just send me a message.

• Remove entire bed
  • Loosen Z belt
  • Remove Z threaded rods and original bed holders. This is easy to do for the 2 smaller corners (on Rapman 3.1 and 3.2) but harder on the other 2 as they are fixed to the corner rods. If you have installed my replacement corners (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4398) then it is a 2 minute job, otherwise take your time to either dismantle the upper corner or simply break the acrylic holding the corner rods (if you have faith in my design :)
  • Remove bed holders from threaded rods but BE CAREFUL and aim the bed holder at the ground as the nut will fly off due to the spring.
  • Replace the 2 nuts onto the threaded rod and put the spring aside.
  • Reinstall the threaded rods and reassemble the corners if necessary. MAKE SURE the Z belt goes around each threaded rod, but DON'T fit and tighten the Z belt just yet.
  • Cut 4 lengths of 12mm-diameter rod (wood, aluminium, etc) to 365mm in length.
  • Drill 5mm-6mm holes 7.5mm in from each end of each rod. The centres of these holes should be 350mm apart.
  • Wind the 2 nuts on the threaded rod so they are just far apart enough for the small bed holder parts to fit around them. Secure loosely with M4 bolts at the bottom (refer to photos)
  • Insert rods and secure loosely with more M4 bolts.
  • Tighten bottom M4 bolts first, then top bolts on the rods. The "inner assembly" is now complete.
  • Install linear bearings onto the larger bed holder pieces with M3 bolts, nuts and washers as shown in the photos (3 bearings per corner).
  • Back to the print bed: Disassemble it and prepare just the lower part.
  • Assemble with the lower print bed piece on the printer, and sit it on top of the inner assembly. Tightening the 2 halves together will clamp the 3 bearings on the guide rods.
  • At each corner, insert the springs in the spring receptacles.
  • Install long M3 bolts from underneath and compress the spring before fitting a nut. A nyloc nut would be ideal, but a standard M3 nut with a bit of loctite also works well (you don't want it to shake loose)
  • Install the top part of the bed onto the bottom part, omitting the springs as the corners now provide the spring action. You may need a spacer depending on clearance.
  • Level the 4 bed corners by turning the Z rods at each corner, then re-fit the Z belt.

comments.text:
To be honest, this has proved to be more difficult than it looks. I don't have a heated bed so I have serious warping issues when printing large parts like this, close together. I have tried to break apart the STL file into individual pieces, but that causes more headache than wasting time and ABS on trying out different build settings. Chylld, could you please post the individual pieces like you did with your corner parts? (which where brilliant btw!) That would be of great help,
Thank you!
comments.author: TheBugtens

comments.text:
Sorry to hear you're having trouble with warp. You can print the parts in PLA (like I did) but in the meantime I suggest you get a heated bed anyway as it's so simple.
I use a flat heating element (http://www.conrad.de/ce/de/product/532886/HEIZFOLIE-320-X-137-MM)http://www.conrad.de/ce/de/pro... sandwiched between a 5mm aluminium plate and a bamboo cutting board from the dollar shop. Runs off the 12V from a spare computer PSU (no other electronics). It gets to about 40-45C which is enough for my purposes but not hot enough to burn :)
comments.author: TheBugtens

comments.text:
We took your advice and ordered a heated bed, and a roll of PLA along with the extra ball bearings needed for the bed holders. I also managed to isolate the two larger parts (using blender,) so that we could print only the ones we needed. (They look terrible though; my brother decided to go for a 0.5 mm layer height, so we might be looking at a reprint with the heated bed)
Our next project is going to have to be a fan duct. I'm not sure that I can use yours though, since I need some of the air to blow on the aluminum piece on top of the heating element to keep my precious PTFE tube from melting... again...
quick question, if I may... Do you still use Axon? or is it just me that still uses it...?
Anyway, thanks a million for this, and for all your other stuff!
comments.author: chylld

comments.text:
0.5mm layer height is extremely thick; I normally print at 0.18mm. I ditched Axon a long time ago for KISSlicer and Skeinforge, and now use just KISSlicer.
Especially with PLA I also have PTFE tube melting problems, so I made a small bracket to mount a 60x12mm fan at the rear of the extruder carriage/duct. It aims up into the top of the hot end and I haven't had a jam since! I also printed a deflector so that the main ducts didn't cool down the tip of the hot end directly (http://puu.sh/a36AI/8b6fc0cea3.jpg)http://puu.sh/a36AI/8b6fc0cea3.... I'll upload these 2 parts to the carriage thing (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:15044)http://www.thingiverse.com/thi... tonight.
comments.author: TheBugtens

comments.text: Thanks a million, chylld, i just finished assembling my rig, and 80%(or more) of the wobble is gone! It's practically usable! :) I admit, it takes a few days to make and bake everything, but it's DAMN WORTH IT. You're a freaking genius and this is an amazing design!
comments.author: Daemon

comments.text: Thanks Chylld, I just replaced my bed holders with your anti-wobble, and am in the middle of the first print.  I can already tell that most of the z-wobble is gone. Everything fit great...I also printed all the parts without support because I was being lazy, but all seems to work.
comments.author: jareed85

comments.text: Ohh... video finally highlights what everyone was talking about by wobble... I must be one of a very few people with straight z-axis threaded rods, or is that something that develops?
comments.author: Kenku

comments.text: Unfortunately it does develop a bit by itself, but starting with straight rods is always advantageous.
comments.author: Kenku

comments.text: Looking at this again and doing some shopping around, was there a reason you went with the ball bearings instead of LM5UU (or something) linear bearings?  At least from my local suppliers the linear bearings look less expensive.
comments.author: chylld

comments.text: 2 main reasons:
comments.author: Kenku

comments.text: Hm, hadn't actually measured the rods.  Wonder if there's any reason why actual 8mm ones couldn't be substituted... though maybe I should stop reinventing the wheel.
comments.author: chylld

comments.text: So this is 8 bolts and 12 bearings per corner?
comments.author: MarcusWolschon

comments.text: Total sorry... 2 bolts and 3 bearings per corner :)
comments.author: MarcusWolschon

This joint can be inserted into the forearm component of the Unlimbited Arm (http://www.teamunlimbited.org/the-unlimbited-arm/) to allow it to be printed in two parts. This allows each part to be printed on a 3D printer with a limited size printbed. It was recently used to join a forearm for an adult that was approximately 300mm (12") long which was printed on and 8" x 8" printbed. The two subcomponents can be printed in PLA and joined using thick CA glue (such as Superglue) then thermoformed as usual. I'd recommend leaving the joint for at least a day to set after gluing before thermoforming.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Folger RepRap 2020 Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm layers

Infill:

35%

comments.text:
Hey Mr John
Thanks for sharing such a great thing
One question, is the the glue you suggested can be thermal treated?
If so can you please show how it looks
I would use an epoxy but after the thermoforming it would stick greatly without allowing the the forearm to have errors or get damaged easily where the glue is
comments.author: x7moodx

comments.text: I used a thick cyanoacrylate (CA) glue such as Superglue. I recommend coating all of the mating edges carefully making sure not to use too much glue. The resulting piece can then be thermoformed as though it had been printed as one component. I've not had any breakages.
comments.author: x7moodx

description.text:
When I bought a razor it came with a free "STAR WARS Razor Stand". WOOT - I thought. Unfortunately after some confusion about how the two pieces went together to do their job, I found from a picture on facebook that the "Stand" was really a "Rest" - and a poor one at that. So as usual, 3D printing.

This model turns this:
https://www.facebook.com/SchickMenAu/photos/p.958965677484930/958965677484930/?type=3

into something usable.

title: Replicator bed level jig for dial gauge with 20x8mm shaft

description.text:
Replicator bed level jig for dial gauge with 20x8mm shaft  
imported original into sketchup and re-modeled for metric guage with 8mm diameter 20mm length shaft.  
Gives about 3mm of movement on bed so might move the collar up in the shaft hole to lessen the pressure on the bed.  
uploaded a version 3. stronger magnetic sockets and re-designed to print without support on its back.
printed with 2 shells and 25% fill I will do another with 3 shells as I got a crack when inserting the magnet in the plain end. Magnets are same 1/4" x 1/4" rare earth. ebay ÃÂ£5 for 18.

comments.text: Hi, I'm the author of one of the parts that ShivInteger mixed into this bricolage.  I just posted this a comment on one of ShivInteger's most recent forray into my activity feed, but the points are still valid for this old entry.  I hope anyone who accidentally finds themselves here is able to draw their own conclusions about this work.
comments.author: mccand

author: shivinteger

title: DailyEarring#104:#2 Pencil (short, with and without erazor)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I don't remember the last time when I used a pencil like this.
. . . . . -> Daily Earring prologue: thingiverse.com/thing:7120
She does, anyway... Maybee there will be a new version in a bit, wich houses a small ballpen tubus.
Print laying (solid ring & higher detail of the lead center but rough side) or standing on the erazor (higher side details and erazor look ontop, but weaker ring)

comments.text: Hi, you should turn this upside down for easier printing.
comments.author: Quixote_sk

comments.text: Everyone can print it as he or she wants (or are there printing programs that can not trotate a model?), it printed fine standing on the erazor side - at least on my printer with minimal support. The details may come out better, as the raft-side can look a bit rough.
comments.author: Quixote_sk

comments.text: damn you make a lot of stuff lol

title: FPV Micro Drone Quadcopter BeanCopter V5

description.text:
This is a microcopter developed for a microquad workshop in Fab Lab Seoul.
FPV equipment embedded under the flight controller.
It is very light and fast to print so you can replace it very fast in case of crash.

Designed together with a screen-remote holder:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1504702

Or an fpv cardboard headset to be cutted in a lasercutter or manually:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1504718

Full tutorial here:
http://eduardochamorro.github.io/beansreels/indextutorials.html

Video example
https://vimeo.com/163513707

V5 Characteristics:
-motors designed for 7mm class
-optional 6mm motor mount
-optional reinforced arms
-electronic mounted on the top for more accuracy/balance
-lipo protected on the bottom ( semienclosed)
-arms design very resistant but flexible for absorbing crashes

For this model the fpv equipment is:
-Coaxial wire as dipole antenna
-Microcamera 600tv 3gr
-Trasmitter TX5823
-Polulu voltage regulator or another 150mah lipo for clean/separate power supply

All the electronic and motor are easy to access.
The motor holders are flexible so you can attach motors 7-6mm size.
For the test model the flight controller used is microwii with dms2 receiver on board but a wide variety on flight controllers can be mounted.

V4 model link :
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1484268
V2-3 model link:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1484253
V1 model link :
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1484249

Printer Brand:

Deltaprintr

Printer:

Deltaprintr Assembled

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1-0.2

Infill:

10-20%

Notes:

Very tolerant model you can print with almost any settings. Printing without supports it is possible if the speed is 80mm/s or higher on a well calibrated printer

Congratulations on your purchase of a Schofield Tools 211-V Directed Energy Plasma Cutter! The 211-V combines power and reliability in a portable form factor, allowing for one-handed operation.

The Plasma Cutter delivers a cohesive pulse-stream, or "bolt", of ionized plasma when fired. It is capable of firing bolts vertically (primary firing mode) and horizontally (secondary firing mode). The Plasma Cutter is very accurate, utilizing three blue lasers to indicate the desired cutting plane.

On impact with the target, bolt cohesion fails frontward first, penetrating the target with a focused jet of superheated matter. This causes intense localized shear effects as well as a tunnelling thermal expansion. When used upon brittle, frozen rocks riddled with faults, it can split them open in one or two shots in skilled hands. Against pliable targets, however, impact will cause minimal damage and thermal expansion will not so much cut as stress the area around the impact site, sometimes requiring several consecutive hits with the non-upgraded tool. Still, when presented with a less than effective alternative against dense organic matter, the 211-V Plasma Cutter retains its utility.

Video: https://youtu.be/oI-qG2dK5ow
Instructables build guide: http://www.instructables.com/id/Dead-Space-Schofield-Tools-211-V-Plasma-Cutter/

I've probably spent hundreds of hours on this - I originally made it for a costume in 2014 but it was a very rough design and some of the moving parts were unreliable. This year I've decided to revive it, clean it up, make it durable, and add some extra features.

The Plasma Cutter features a rotating front barrel capable of mounting either three lasers, or for a cosplay-safe version, three LEDs. The LEDs take up considerably less space which enabled me to design a mechanism to extend the 'fins' on the front of the cutter, making it more game-accurate. The actual movement of the fins in-game can only be described as 'physics defying' as they move through parts of the model, but extending the fins IRL still looks damn cool!

Most of the design is my own, but I borrowed and modified the grip from this Seburo M5: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:175053, and this rack and pinion: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:21206

title: Print-Rite DIY - Self Lubricating Bearing Bushing holder

description.text:
This part is made to replace the original weak bearing fixation.
You will need this type of bearing :

http://fr.aliexpress.com/item/10pcs-Wear-Resisting-SF-1-Self-Lubricating-Bearing-Bushing-8mm-x-10mm-x-12mm/32275233980.html?isOrigTitle=true

They perform a good job, with absolutely no noise, and a good translation.
You can put one or two bearing per fixation, personnaly I use only one.

Print them vertically so the face in contact with the plate is really plane.

I printed them with support in the center, but you can try without.
Infill as you wish, 20% is enough.

title: Pen spring DA OTF knife
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is DA OTF knife made only with a pen spring.

  • DA OTF - Double action out the front

which means, blade of the knife can be opened and retracted with single switch.

it is a form of automatic knife which is illegal for civilians to carry around, so

!Here is warning;

Please, Do NOT carry this around if you happened to make this. Also, I highly recommend not to modify the blade; it is purposely designed round so it cannot harm anyone.

That being said,

*Printing tips & instruction

  1. This one is printed in ABS, I am not sure how it will work with other materials.

  2. I recommend you to use "brim" around parts, to prevent warping.

  3. "Support structure" are not necessary.

  4. After print, make sure you sand interlocking parts, so they can move freely, especially blade.

Leave me comments if you have questions.

Happy printing~

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Notes:

I used ABS plastic, and printed with brim around parts.
Moving parts might need sanding

description.text: The design files for this thing have been removed as a protest against Stratasys after their decision to file a patent infringement lawsuit against Microboards Technology. Their decision is extremely destructive and also underlines that the patent system is obsolete as it no longer serves any purpose for the betterment of society. Its main role is as a blunt weapon used by incumbents to hamper innovation. I see absolutely no reason to continue indirectly supporting Stratasys by providing free content to Thingiverse.
This model is a mutation of the Xenobird sample project from Substance3D (Neurosystems)

All parts can be printed without using support structures, but part5 may have to be cleaned up a bit if not using support.
Sand the flat edges of each piece and glue together to create the model. If there are any visible seams, they can be fixed by brushing with ABS/Acetone solution and then sanded

print_settings.Notes:: Please note, measurements are almost exactly to scale, which means either you need an accurate printer, or you may need some post processing.

description.text:
I ordered PTFE tubing for my Bowden conversion upgrade. However I was sent the wrong size adapter for the tube. Rather than 6, your standard extruder size, I received 9M.

So I designed a quick fix adapter while I wait for the metal part to arrive.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Geeetech Prusa i3 Aluminium

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

30% +

Notes:

I suggest using no infill, even though I did, this will get you a strong reliable adapter. I mean after all it will be the bridge between two metal components.

Print at 0.1 Resolution in order for the thread to print. Fan Cooling is highly recommended. (I just had a PC fan aimed at the bed area.

Please note, measurements are almost exactly to scale, which means either you need an accurate printer, or you may need some post processing.

comments.text: Many thanks from me as well. Allowed me to start playing with my newly built HPCE instead of waiting for the boat to arrive ..

print_settings.Notes:: This uses a 608 Scooter bearing as you can see in the pic. I suggest a reasonable infill 25-30% as this will not be under any strain. The "legs" of the base can be easily warped to suit your needs, in my case I formed them into a very slight dome, so they fit the surface neatly. (you do this by heating it up with a hair dryer (if PLA)). The hole sizes may need some sanding down to suit your friction needs.

description.text:
A holder for my FR632 diversity receiver, since I am using a Fatshark BASE model and I don't want to use a groundstation I needed something to mount it to the strap of the goggles. It's a bit thicker than the receiver, because I added some Velcro there (to mount the receiver elsewhere), works great as padding though.

On the bottom I just left space for the power in and diversity video out (never needed the other 2 outputs)

author: Vasconnesso74

title: Sony Z3 / Nexus 5X bike mount [Flex material]

description.text:
This holder is designed to hold a Sony Z3 with a TPU cover. I have also tried it with a Nexus 5X (with TPU cover) and it was a tight fit. The holder has a lip on the inside which holds on to the bottom edge of the TPU cover. My phone and cover measures roughly 75 mm x 10 mm so scale accordingly to fit other phones.

Print in Flex material and mount this on the stem with nylon zip ties. I think it can be printed with a harder material as well, then you'll probably need to cut off a piece of inner tube and stick it between the holder and the stem.

EDIT: Added stl optimized for Nexus 5X, added hole for charging.

author: Marrrs

title: 15mm Bottle Rocket Collar with O Ring Support

description.text:
This is a bottle rocket launch mechanism designed to be glued onto standard 15mm copper pipe, and a take a dual pin lock / release (we used garden weed mat staples).

Has a groove for a standard 15mm O ring (e.g. for taps) to provide seal for bottle. Tested with 2.25l Lift bottles in New Zealand.

We used to make tall launchers which released from above head height to make safer.

Use / adapt at your own risk of course.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/3LvWytATFjp

In teaching myself Grasshopper for Rhino 3D I decided to use this Delta vase by the amazing Dutch designer Mart van Schijndel as a model because I liked its deceptively simple geometry and was curious what an algorithm for this shape would do with more sides and different dimensions. The original is only made of three planes of glass, so printing it in 3d sort of loses the simplicity! Here is a link to the original: http://www.martvanschijndel.nl/en/product-design/project/56/delta-vaas-1981 I have also included two other outputs from the algorithm - a six sided shotglass size thing and a seventeen sided tall vase thing.

I have included the Rhino 3D file and the Grasshopper script.  In Grasshopper I defined the algorithm in two ways.  Plug point D into either #1 or #2.  There are sliders for height, width and number of sides.

title: 300 AAC / Blackout Brass Trimming jig for Cutoff Saw

description.text:
This is a jig to work with the Harbor Freight #42307 Mini Cut-Off saw to trim .223 / 5.56x45 cases down to make 300 AAC cases.   
The jig uses two of the saw mounting holes to position the case for trimming just behind the shoulder of the case. The jig is designed to position the case based on the shoulder rather than the case mouth to eliminate variations due to case neck length. The pocket also has an additional 0.050" wall around it to better hold and position the case than a simple half-round pocket.   
The saw vise must be removed from the saw base to use this and a 0.050 shim placed under the jig due to a slight raised lip where the vise normally mounts. I tried several times to print an undercut using support but did not have very satisfactory results.   Some tweaking of the position is required to get just behind the shoulder. There is enough slop in the mounting holes to do this. I use 1/8" x 2" toggle bolts to clamp the jig and mount it to the workbench.   
This is a work in progress. I am looking at ways to make the cut off neck easier to remove, eject or drop away. I will post that version when I perfect it. In the mean time I am including both the STL file as well as the Solidworks file if you care to modify the design.

Printer: Rostock 3D Max
Material: Zen Toolworks 1.75mm White PLA (Amazon)
Slicer: Cura 13.06.4
Layer Height: 0.15mm
Shell Thickness: 0.45mm
Print Speed: 60mm/sec
Head Temp: 190 C
Bed Temp: 70 C
Bed Material: Borosilicate Glass with Aquanet Extra Hold Coating
Support: None

comments.text: I think you meant to say .556x45 in your description rather than 7.62x51.
comments.author: sirsumm

comments.text: You are correct sir! and the first to catch it. It has been corrected.
comments.author: sirsumm

comments.text: Ok... it was 4 a.m. but I had to try it. Rough cut (without clamping anything) cut a 223 right at the case neck just as he designed. Good job! I see what you mean by the case neck still "hanging around" in the jig. Also possibly putting a "stop" at the base will keep the case from slipping to the right as you are cutting and maybe a "finger" hole (or simple depression) for case removal after cutting. For fat fingered users. You saved me tons of time and your design didn't take but a lil over an hour to print on a flash forge creator pro (20% infill). I originally got this idea from a commercial jig on youtube can be viewed here. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6q-N4nai6_4

A test-run of a reed blade. See if you can print this cleanly, in any orientation & on any printer. If you get a clean print, let me know. If you get two of them, you might be able to make a working reed. Instructions on making a traditional reed are available on YouTube - search Colin Ross reedmaking. The reed Colin is making has slightly different dimensions in places to this one (and is made from cane), but the principles are more or less the same.

comments.text:
Hello!
That's a good idea you had! You probably already discover a such 3d printed reed wouldn't work in part because of the hardness and the lack of flexibility of PLA (I don't know that of ABS, maybe...)... or perhaps not, so I'll share my recent research on 3d printed double reeds with you (I'm far from having THE solution ;-)).
I'll recommand you that you try printing the reed flat, and then shape it as you want with some plyers. Be carefull though not to bend too much towards the tip of the reed, or the reed will be to flappy, flat (low pitched) and will require too much air. Personnally, I never bend the lasts 5-8 milimeters of the reed.
Don't hesitate to contact me if you have suggestions or questions!
Regards and good luck!
comments.author: RexConstenla
